awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Resaerch:  The Legal Incorporation of Private Regulation: Transforming Ratings in Finance and Healthcare
awd_abstract_narration:
SES- 1603041
Elizabeth Gorman 
Joris Gjata
University of Virginia

Ratings have become a symbol of the power of information to regulate lives. They are condensed ways of presenting information about people, organizations, or their products and activities. They take different forms and come from different sources. However, only some of these ratings have gained tremendous regulatory power over the lives of individuals and organizations as they evaluate compliance with certain standards of behavior. Most scholars and analysts regard ratings? regulatory power an inevitable, natural and functional response to conditions of increasing market expansion and uncertainty. This project examines the evolution of ratings and their sources for two large sectors - finance and healthcare - in the United States. In both fields ratings with regulatory power come from a few specialized private agencies. The recognition by law of those few specialized private agencies - credit rating and hospital accrediting agencies respectively - as legitimate sources of information to evaluate organizations? worth, is a key moment in the history of ratings for both fields. How and why were specific private agencies recognized as legitimate sources of ratings instead of alternative governmental or professional forms of regulation? How did ratings gain their regulatory power over healthcare and financial organizations? What was the role of the state and law in the emergence of ratings as a new institution? How did their meaning change over time? The answers to these questions will highlight institutional configurations without neglecting the agents that make possible their maintenance, change and stability. They also contribute to the demystification of new regulatory forms as inevitable, natural and functional outcomes necessitated by conditions of uncertainty and increasing market expansion. The comparison of two different fields helps reveal the interdependences of different fields and the crucial role policy makers play in shaping new forms of regulation: legitimizing them, contributing to their implementation, and mediating their power to shape social life. 

This project will combine data on congressional records and hearings about the formal recognition in federal legislation of certain specialized private agencies as legitimate sources of ratings, organizational histories and accounts, examinations of field specific publications, and newspaper data to trace the processes through which regulation-by-information emerged as a new institutional form in two major fields of activity in the US. It uses theories of institutional emergence to examine the political and cultural struggles surrounding the emergence of ratings by certain specialized private agencies as regulation-by-information and the sidelining of alternative sources of ratings like associations or government agencies. The project aims to clarify the meaning of ratings, the conditions under which they constitute ?regulation-by-information,? and present a more coherent framework for examining other emerging forms of regulation.

por.por_cntn:
Joris Gjata was able to complete the research needed for her dissertation “The Private Roots and Public Branches of Regulation-by-Information: Understanding The Legal Incorporation of Rating in Finance and Accreditation in Healthcare (1900s-1970s)” thanks to the support of the NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant. During her funding period, she gathered and analyzed documents from several different sources regarding the history of ratings—rating of securities and accreditation of hospitals—in the United States: records and hearings from Congress and other government organizations, archival material from and about the providers of ratings, relevant trade and professional associations connected to, using or affected by the ratings, and the major newspapers covering ratings and their providers. As a sociologist interested in economics, politics, and organizations, Gjata was interested in understanding why and how ratings from certain private providers of ratings became so powerful regulators, ending up mentioned and recognized in government rules, regulations, and legislation as legitimate evaluators and adjudicators of the worth of many organizations and their products. More specifically, she concentrated on what these private organizations that provided ratings themselves—the largest and oldest are Moody’s and Standard and Poor (S&P) in finance and The Joint Commission (TJC) and the Healthcare Facilities Accreditation Program (HFAP) in healthcare—did to be recognized and incorporated in law, and what happened to alternative sources of ratings—business and professional associations or government agencies.

Through her historical and comparative analysis and her interdisciplinary approach to regulation, Gjata fulfilled the goal of her research, wrote her dissertation and shared her findings with interested individuals and organizations both from the private and public sector. She also mentored two undergraduate students on doing research in the social sciences while they assisted during two summer terms in searching, finding, selecting, collecting, organizing, and summarizing documents and other material from different sources.

The data Gjata collected and analyzed during the funding period, especially those from the providers of ratings—rating agencies in finance and accreditation organizations in healthcare—make the foundation for her argument that the way these private provider organizations built their identity—the way they presented their product of rating and themselves in relationship to existing products and organizations in each sector—contributed to them being selected and incorporated in law. In both cases, the private ‘independent’ organization that provided ratings gained regulatory power as it became increasingly more public. It did so through two venues, specifically: first, by offering their rating product as an evaluation to supplement those of other organizations and help those that needed more information about the quality of securities; and second, by presenting themselves as independent reliable producers of information with expertise in gathering, processing and presenting information not just in the form of rating, but in the form of other high quality ‘objective’ products.

Gjata also noted that there was more political contestation around the legal incorporation of the providers of ratings in healthcare—accreditation organizations—than around those in finance—credit rating agencies. Her analysis suggests that such differences are the result of the extent to which each sector has well-established organized professions, with older and more established professional groups in healthcare rather than in finance. The dissertation she completed in December 2017 is an important contribution to the sociological studies of regulation because she shows how regulation emerges and transforms in form and meaning, and offers an approach to explaining such transformations. While some scholars consider ratings to be a new form of regulation—what they call ‘regulation-by-information’—Gjata calls for more attention to clarifying what is old and what is new about the regulatory power of these information products. Her work asserts that the transformation of ratings through the legal incorporation of certain private organizations changed the identity of the regulator—from being mostly private to becoming increasingly public—and therefore produced a different kind of regulation. Gjata’s research also contributes to the sociology of markets that takes seriously the role of organizations, including not only private firms but also professional and government organizations.
